edm:ProvidedCHO.dc:subject: Agriculture
edm:ProvidedCHO.dc:description: Professor Todd (1921-1991) was an extension professor of plant pathology at North Carolina State University and a North Carolina native. "He was known as 'Mr. Tobacco' to researchers, farmers, and politicians across North Carolina and was lauded for his work as a plant pathologist for his ability to turn the science of growing a bug-free tobacco leaf into workable, money-saving practices for tobacco growers" (N&O, March 4, 1991). Among his many honors are Man of the Year from the Progressive Farmer (1972), Tar Heel of the Week, Raleigh News and Observer (1977), and Fellow of the American Phytopathological Society (1978).
edm:ProvidedCHO.dc:title: Extension professor, Furney A. Todd, lecturing in tobacco field
edm:ProvidedCHO.dc:subject: Tobacco

foaf:Organization.skos:note: North Carolina Agricultural Extension Service is a cooperative service between North Carolina State University, North Carolina Agricultural and Technical University, and the U.S. Dept. of Agriculture; located on campus of N.C. State University.
North Carolina Agricultural Research Service is part of the NCSU School of Agriculture and Life Sciences. Previously, the North Carolina Agricultural Experiment Station.
